Acquisition of Firma expected to be largely complete by publication date.
Focus on retaining Firma team and delivering EPS accretion of 20%.

elements.title: Notes to the financial statements for the year ended 31 March 2022
Independent auditor’s report to the shareholders of OFX Group Limited

data.value: We have audited the Financial Report of OFX Group Limited (the Company). In our opinion, the accompanying Financial Report of the Company is in accordance with the Corporations Act 2001, including: giving a true and fair view of the Group’s financial position as at 31 March 2022 and of its financial performance for the year ended on that date;

Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as at 31 March 2022; Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income, Consolidated Statement of Changes in Equity, and Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows for the year then ended; Notes including a summary of significant accounting policies; and Directors’ Declaration.
We conducted our audit in accordance with Australian Auditing Standards. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion.

We are independent of the Group in accordance with the Corporations Act 2001 and the ethical requirements of the Accounting Professional and Ethical Standards Board’s APES 110 Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants.
KPMG, an Australian partnership and a member firm of the KPMG global organisation of independent member firms affiliated with KPMG International Limited.

elements.title: Independent auditor’s report to the Shareholders of OFX Group Limited

data.value: The Independent auditor's report covers the responsibilities of the Directors for the Financial Report and the auditor's responsibilities in relation to the audit.
Preparing the Financial Report, implementing internal controls, and assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern.
Obtaining reasonable assurance that the Financial Report is free from material misstatement and issuing an Auditor’s Report.
Misstatements considered material if they influence economic decisions of users based on the Financial Report.

We remain committed to the strategy we laid out in FY19 and have refined each year. We see the increasing regulatory focus which we believe we have is a competitive strength of ours. We believe that increasing interest rates and the challenge competition are facing with their path to profitability as being new and positive tailwinds for us, because our team, our execution, have never been better. Our customers are experiencing that and our investors are seeing that. There are still several risks we must navigate – most notably the increase in cyber risk, increasing societal expectations of good governance, and in the war for talent. However, we feel as well placed as ever to manage those on your behalf, as we continue to build a strong, sustainable Company. I want to thank my fellow Directors for their dedication and commitment when the Company needed it. Their dedication is extraordinary, especially in the context of more scrutiny, more time that is required for mergers and acquisitions, and higher expectations from investors. Finally, on behalf of our clients and our partners, I want to thank Skander and the OFX team for their extraordinary hard work, skill and perseverance in these uncertain times.
Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director

Skander Malcolm's message highlights flexible working arrangements, commitment to learning, employee recognition through salary adjustments and stock grants, and the resilience of the company through challenging times.

elements.title: STI Outcomes and Executive Compensation for FY22
Remuneration report for the financial year ended 31 March 2022

data.value: This table appears to be a performance evaluation matrix for three individuals (S Malcolm, S Verth, and M Shaw) across various business metrics. The evaluation uses ratings including 'Outstanding', 'Exceeds', 'Meets', and '/A' (presumably Not Applicable). S Verth shows particularly strong performance with Outstanding ratings in M&A strategy and Exceeds in several areas. Overall, both S Malcolm and S Verth received 'Exceeds' for their overall individual performance, while M Shaw received 'Meets.'

This table shows the bonus pool calculation breakdown for FY22 compared to FY21. The calculation is based on five components: Underlying EBITDA and NOI (each weighted 30%), Strategic Investments and Risk/ESG (each weighted 20%), and Board Discretion. Notable performance includes EBITDA increase from $29.1m to $44.5m (53.1% growth) and NOI growth from $117.9m to $147.0m (24.7% growth). Both EBITDA and NOI achieved 110% payout rates, contributing 33% each to the total funding. The total funding adds up to 100%, with Strategic Investments contributing 15%, Risk and ESG 17%, and Board Discretion 2%.

elements.title: Remuneration report for the financial year ended 31 March 2022

data.value: The Board retains wide discretion to adjust formulaic incentive outcomes up or down (including to zero) prior to their finalisation. Malus refers to the exercise of downward discretion. Clawback refers to the Board’s power to recover awards or payments that have been made, granted or vested.
If a change of control occurs prior to the vesting of share rights that are not subject to performance hurdles the Board has discretion to bring forward vesting dates.

data.key: Minimum shareholding requirements for Non-Executive Directors
data.value: A minimum shareholding requirement for Non-Executive Directors was introduced in FY19. Each Non-Executive Director must establish and maintain a level of share ownership equal to one times’ the Non-Executive Director’s annual base fee.
All Directors and employees are required to comply with the Group’s Securities Trading Policy in undertaking any trading in the Company’s shares.

The Board seeks to set fees for the Non-Executive Directors that reflect the demands and responsibilities of the Directors, at a level to attract and retain Directors of the highest quality. Non-Executive Director fees will be reviewed from time to time.
There were no changes in fees for Non-Executive Directors during FY22.
The maximum amount payable to be shared by all Non-Executive Directors is currently set at $1,000,000 per annum.
Non-Executive Directors do not receive any equity or performance-related compensation.
Non-Executive Directors receive superannuation contributions where required by Superannuation Guarantee legislation.
Chairperson fee: $200,000, Base Director fee: $100,000, Committee Chair fee: $25,000, Committee Member fee: $15,000.

This table shows the remuneration details for Non-Executive Directors, including cash salary, fees, and superannuation for 2022 and the previous year. The total remuneration increased from $644,582 to $725,000. S Sargent received the highest compensation at $230,000 in both years. Most directors maintained consistent total remuneration across both years, with some variations in the split between cash salary and superannuation.

elements.title: Notes to the financial statements for the year ended 31 March 2022

data.value: Under AASB 16, leases are recognised as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding liability.
Each lease payment is allocated between the liability and finance cost.
Finance cost is charged to profit or loss over the lease period.
The right-of-use asset is depreciated over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term.
Rental contracts are typically made for fixed periods of three to 10 years.
The lease agreements do not impose any covenants.
Measured on a present value basis including fixed payments.
Lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease.
Used when the interest rate implicit cannot be determined.
Measured at cost and includes initial measurement of lease liability.
Remeasured to reflect reassessment or modification.
Payments for these leases are recognised as an expense in profit or loss.

elements.title: Independent auditor’s report to the Shareholders of OFX Group Limited
Key Audit Matter regarding Tax Arrangements

data.value: Tax is considered a key audit matter due to the complexity of concessional tax arrangements used by the Group during the year.
Working with our tax specialists, we performed the following procedures: Evaluated the relation to the tax arrangements.
A subsidiary of the Group, OzForex Limited, qualifies as an Offshore Banking Unit (OBU), which attracts a concessional tax rate of 10%.
We assessed the OBU legal status against relevant Australian tax legislation.
Eligibility for Research and Development Tax Credits (R&D Credits) which further reduces the Group's tax expense.
Obtained a sample of trades recorded in the OBU and checked their features against the allocation methodology.

continuing to improve our technology platform to enable operations at scale, lowering costs and enhancing security for our clients and shareholders.
building trust through strong risk management across regulators, clients, bankers and partners.
greater emphasis to build our Global Operating Model so that our teams can serve customers locally and grow their global careers with OFX.
risk that changes in banking and financial services licensing regulations could adversely affect the Group’s profitability.
risk of failing to comply with laws or having inadequate compliance procedures in relation to client on-boarding and money laundering detection.
risks associated with the performance, reliability, and availability of technology platforms which could impact operations.
Potential faults in the Group’s technology platform could cause transaction errors, resulting in legal exposure, damage to reputation, and regulatory breaches.
Ineffective data security controls could lead to cyber-attacks, loss of sensitive data, regulatory actions, and business interruptions.
Failure to comply with privacy regulations may result in fines, investigations, and restrictions affecting business operations.
Loss of significant banking relationships could restrict foreign exchange services and increase operating costs.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to the Group's Business Operations

data.value: Possible withdrawal of services or change in business model affecting risk levels and profitability.
Risk of incorrect funds transfer requiring recovery actions and potential liability for erroneous transactions.
Risk of being liable for amounts related to fraudulent transfers although steps taken to recover funds.
Impact of currency movements on transactions affecting clients and Group's performance.
Risk of counterparties failing to pay settlement amounts on forward exchange contracts.
Increased competition risking attractiveness of services leading to changes in business model affecting profitability.
Market risk is comprised of both foreign currency risk and interest rate risk.

Arises from exposure to changes in foreign exchange rates between the time of agreeing rates with a client and either a corresponding hedge being taken out with a counterparty or an international payment settlement.
Exposure to non-traded interest rate risk results from cash and term deposits held in different currencies.
The risk that creditors (clients and financial institutions) will not make payments on their receivables and derivatives respectively, when they fall due.

elements.title: Fraud and financial crime prevention and protection

data.value: Monitoring customer interaction and utilizing third party information to detect potential concerns such as identity theft.
Regular tracking and discussion of financial crime controls at management, executive and Board levels.
Regular independent assessments through audits of AML programs, banking compliance reviews and regulatory reviews.
OFX is committed to being ethical, transparent, and accountable.
Employees are empowered to recognize risk.
Maintaining experienced compliance teams in key regions to ensure compliance with local regulations.
Continuing to invest in technology for effective risk monitoring.
For FY22, governance practices complied with ASX Corporate Governance Council’s Principles and Recommendations.
CEO discusses the importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives.

elements.title: CEO’s message on ESG initiatives and commitments

data.value: Established to advance the ESG program and drive meaningful impact.

1. Investing in a sustainable future - focus on decarbonisation and Net Zero.
2. Empowering people globally and locally - emphasis on inclusion, diversity, and community engagement.
3. Global financial responsibility - prioritising fraud awareness and ISO270001 certification.
Data Privacy, Cyber Security, Compliance, Transparent pricing.
Adopted by OFX Board of Directors in March 2022.

data.value: FY21: -, FY22: 5, Target for FY23: >= number of new high risk initiatives involving customer personal information
OFX is not a high consumer of energy but committed to monitoring, reducing and offsetting consumption.
Providing recycling facilities, laptops to reduce printing, reusable take-away cups, and online tools to minimize paper use.
Operating 100% in the cloud with AWS, which is more energy efficient.
Encouraging employees to participate in environmental community initiatives.
Educating employees about environmental impact and recycling.
Actions we undertook Monitor paper, electricity and water consumption, minimise employee travel and investigate carbon offsets for air travel.
Consumption and employee travel was reduced in part due to COVID-19 restrictions.
Electronic signatures are used globally for all non-disclosure agreements, vendor agreements, order forms and employment documents.

A network of community champions was established which promotes participation in community activities, including soap recycling in Hong Kong, lunch preparation at a homeless shelter and gardening for an environmental group in Sydney.
OFX has engaged with a specialist online platform to help it document and calculate carbon emissions globally.
Through both reduction initiatives and offsets, obtain carbon neutral status for our Australian business and begin the journey to becoming certified as carbon neutral for the OFX business globally.

Employees encouraged to volunteer and participate
Building a culture and working environment for diverse backgrounds and inclusion.
46% Caucasian/White, 12% South East Asian, 10% East Asian, 10% South Asian.
Completed for Workplace Gender Equality Agency.
Average female base salary -12.11% compared to male.
Further develop and implement our philanthropy strategy to increase our contribution to victims of financial crime
Formed a partnership with global charity, Save the Children, making a AUD$20,000 donation.
Explore potential partnerships and community engagement opportunities that enable OFX to support Indigenous education and employment
Established a community partnership with the Australian Indigenous Mentoring Experience (AIME).
Further develop our response to the risk of modern slavery
Introduced an enhanced due diligence process on high-risk vendors and improved employee educational resources, including Modern Slavery training undertaken by all employees in FY22.
Implement our approach to the future of work based on lessons learned and feedback
A hybrid work model was implemented supported by a working from home survey, people leader training and support and risk assessments.
Increase female representation throughout the Company
Increased female representation across the Senior Leadership Team (SLT).
Track cultural diversity data on a voluntary and self-identification basis

Obtained cultural diversity data for the first time, with the level of cultural diversity above that of the countries where most employees are located (Australia, Canada, UK). This level of cultural diversity is above that of the countries in which the majority of our employees are located (Australia, Canada, UK).
Continue to take a proactive role in improving the health and welfare of our people
Introduced Wellbeing month (September), access to mental health provider, Uprise and corporate discounts for fitness providers.

elements.title: FY23 Commitments on Community Partnerships and Diversity Initiatives

data.value: Support victims of financial crime and Indigenous education and employment through education, awareness, fundraising, and volunteer opportunities.
Maintain commitment to gender representation targets, annual pay equity testing, and other inclusion measures.
Increase female representation in leadership pipeline at SLT level.
Aims to maintain gender balance at Global Executive Team level and improve pay equity on average.

elements.title: Cyber security and data privacy initiatives

data.value: Cyber security poses an increasingly significant threat to business globally, with paramount importance on the security of customer data.
Programs designed to foster a strong cyber security culture, including drills and secure coding training.
Set KPIs related to privacy for new CRM system.
Cyber security subject matter experts provide oversight and independent assurance by risk and internal audit.
Complete implementation of the new framework.
Build robust access controls into new CRM system for all internal users.
Continued investment in security capabilities with a variety of technologies and controls to minimize unauthorized access threats.
Monitoring outcomes of the review of Australia’s privacy laws and potential changes to the Privacy Act 1988.

elements.title: Global Financial Responsibility FY22 progress against commitments

data.value: 100% of our business workloads ran on the cloud.
Certification is underway, with certification being worked towards for FY24.
A refreshed data retention policy has detailed Australian and UK retention schedules, incorporating a new framework for managing customer data through its lifecycle.
OFX has developed bespoke staff training on data breach reporting processes.
A new customer risk assessment methodology was agreed.
An educational session for employees was run on how OFX is working to protect customers from financial crime.
New content was posted to the OFX website and emails sent to educate customers on protecting themselves against fraud.
Explore and identify external facing network vulnerabilities and their remediation.
Continue to upgrade our security toolsets primarily on email and vulnerability management.
Continue to elevate our BCP/DR procedures through tabletop and simulation exercises.
Continue to position OFX for ISO270001 Certification.
Continue to enhance our data retention policy.
Improve the process around data mapping.
Embed OFX’s Privacy Impact Assessment process.
Implement enhanced data breach response plans and training for all employees globally.
Ongoing enhancement of customer and partner awareness of scams and how to best protect themselves.
Fraud training and educational content for OFX employees.
